whisper_segments.text: Welcome everyone to our presentation on AI-assisted video editing.
Today we'll be looking at how machine learning can transform the post-production workflow.
First, let me introduce our team and the tools we've been building.
Over the past six months we developed an automated chapter detection system.
It analyzes transcription data and silence patterns to find natural chapter boundaries.
The system uses rule-based heuristics combined with gap analysis.
Let me show you a quick demo of how the chapter detection works in practice.
Now moving on to our second topic, the natural language command interface.
Users can type commands like add chapter markers or color code speakers.
The system translates these into structured edit decisions for DaVinci Resolve.
We use template matching for common commands and an LLM fallback for complex ones.
The dry-run mode lets you preview changes before they are applied.
Our third area of focus has been the smart portrait cropping pipeline.
It uses person detection and tracking to follow speakers in landscape footage.
The output is a nine-by-sixteen portrait crop suitable for YouTube Shorts.
Person tracking uses ultralytics YOLO for real-time bounding box detection.
Let me now discuss integration with DaVinci Resolve Studio.
We connect via the scripting API to create timelines, add markers, and set clip colors.
The bridge serializes all operations through a queue because the API is not thread-safe.
Currently we support six API capabilities that have been live-tested and confirmed.
For the final section I want to talk about the library system.
We scan directories of video files and extract metadata, transcripts, and chapters.
The output is a JSON library file that feeds all of our viewer tools.
Viewers can search transcripts, navigate chapters, and export timecodes.
In conclusion, this pipeline transforms raw footage into searchable structured data.
All processing runs locally on GPU with zero cloud dependencies.
Thank you for your time. I'm happy to take any questions from the audience.
We have about ten minutes for questions before we wrap up the session.
So David, tell us about how the Christmas Carol project started.
It began about four years ago when we first started exploring VR theater.
The idea was to bring classic stories into an immersive virtual environment.
We wanted to see if audiences would connect with Dickens in a VR space.
The technical challenges were significant. We had to figure out motion capture.
Each performer wore a tracking suit and we captured everything in real time.
The live audience was actually in a physical theater watching the VR feed.
The most rewarding part was seeing the audience reactions during live shows.
People would gasp when Marley's ghost appeared because it felt so real.
That emotional connection is what convinced us to keep developing the format.
Looking forward, we want to expand to other classic productions.
There is a lot of interest from educational institutions as well.
Schools want to use VR theater to teach Shakespeare and other classics.
I think the future of theater will include both physical and virtual spaces.
They complement each other rather than competing.
Thank you David, that was a fascinating conversation about VR theater.
Thank you for having me. It's been great to share our journey.
Okay let's run through the opening scene one more time.
Scrooge enters from stage left, the ghost appears from above.
Remember the timing on the lighting cue needs to be tighter this time.
Marley's ghost I need you to hold that position for three more seconds.
The VR camera needs time to capture the full reveal.
Great. Now let's move to the Ghost of Christmas Past sequence.
The transition between past and present needs work.
We should add a particle effect during the scene change.
The audience reported feeling disoriented during the last test.
Final scene. Scrooge wakes up on Christmas morning.
This is the emotional peak, so we need the music to swell here.
Perfect. Let's take five and then do a full run-through.
Everyone did great work today. We're getting close to show-ready.
Welcome to the behind the scenes look at our production.
This is where the motion capture magic happens.
We have twelve cameras positioned around the performance space.
The costume department has been working on period-accurate outfits.
Each costume has tracking markers embedded in the fabric.
This allows us to capture both the performer and the costume movement.
Sound design is another critical component of the VR experience.
We use spatial audio to place sounds in the virtual environment.
When Scrooge walks past you can hear his footsteps shift position.
Post-production involves combining all the captured data streams.
We use DaVinci Resolve for color grading and final assembly.
The AI tools help us detect chapters and organize the timeline.
The entire workflow from capture to final export takes about two weeks.
With the AI pipeline we have cut that down to about three days.
And the quality keeps improving with each iteration.
Good morning. Welcome to the quarterly review for the immersive media division.
I want to start by showing you the progress we have made on the capture pipeline.
Camera A is our wide shot covering the full stage area from the balcony.
Camera B provides the medium shot from stage right focusing on the performers.
Camera C is the close-up roaming camera operated by our steadicam operator.
The multi-camera setup gives us maximum flexibility in post-production.
We can cut between angles without any additional shooting days.
Now let me walk you through the lighting rig we installed last month.
The overhead array uses forty-eight individually addressable LED panels.
Each panel can be controlled via DMX for precise color temperature adjustments.
This gives our color grading team a much more consistent starting point.
The lighting setup reduces color correction time by roughly forty percent.
Moving on to audio. We switched to a wireless lavalier system this quarter.
Each performer wears a miniature microphone hidden in their costume.
The audio feeds are mixed live and also recorded as isolated tracks.
Having isolated audio tracks makes dialogue editing much more precise.
We can remove background noise from individual speakers without affecting others.
The interview segment we recorded last week turned out exceptionally well.
The director spoke about the creative vision behind the VR adaptation.
We captured it with all three cameras running simultaneously.
The AI-assisted editing tools identified twelve chapter boundaries automatically.
Each chapter was tagged with a descriptive title based on the transcript content.
For the next quarter we plan to add real-time preview capability.
The director will be able to see a rough edit as the performance happens.
This requires low-latency processing which is why we upgraded the GPU.
The new card handles inference three times faster than our previous setup.
Budget update. We are currently twenty percent under budget for this quarter.
The savings come primarily from running AI locally instead of using cloud APIs.
Every transcription and detection task runs on our local GPU infrastructure.
This eliminates per-minute API costs that were adding up significantly.
Let me show you the editing workflow we demonstrated to the board last week.
Step one: ingest footage from all cameras into the library system.
Step two: automatic transcription runs on each file using faster-whisper.
Step three: chapter detection finds natural scene boundaries.
Step four: the editor types natural language commands to build the rough cut.
Step five: the system generates edit decisions and applies them in Resolve.
Questions from the team. Sarah asks about the timeline for phase two.
Phase two adds speaker diarization so we can identify who is talking.
This enables automatic speaker labels and color coding in the timeline.
We expect phase two to be ready for testing by the end of next month.
Mike asks about export formats. Currently we support timeline XML and EDL.
We are adding direct YouTube upload with automatic metadata tagging.
The metadata includes chapter markers and description text from the transcript.
Thank you everyone for attending. The next review is in four weeks.
Please reach out if you have questions about any of the tools we discussed.
Have a great rest of your day.
All right let's start the color grading session for the auditorium footage.
The first thing I notice is the white balance is shifted too warm on camera A.
We need to pull the color temperature down to match the other camera angles.
I am going to apply a node-based correction using the primary wheels.
The skin tones on the lead performer look good in the wide shot.
But the close-up has some magenta contamination in the shadows.
Let me add a qualifier to isolate the skin tones and correct just those areas.
The power window tracks the face as it moves through the frame.
Now for the scene transitions. The lighting changes between acts need matching.
Act one uses cool blue tones to suggest the cold winter setting.
Act three shifts to warm amber tones when the story reaches redemption.
I will create reference stills for each act so the look stays consistent.
The VR footage needs special attention because of the wide field of view.
Lens distortion affects the color accuracy at the edges of the frame.
We apply a radial correction that compensates for the optical falloff.
Final pass. I am adding a subtle film grain emulation to unify the look.
This gives the digital footage a more organic cinematic texture.
The grain pattern is randomized per frame so it does not look artificial.
Let me render a preview of the final grade for the director to review.
I am exporting at full resolution with the LUT baked in.
The render should take about twelve minutes on the current hardware.
Color grading is complete. Twenty-three shots graded across five scenes.
I will send the graded timeline to the editor for the final assembly pass.
Next session we tackle the backroom footage.
Today we are working on the spatial audio mix for the auditorium performance.
The goal is to place each sound source in three-dimensional space.
When the audience wears headphones they should feel surrounded by the performance.
I am loading the eight-channel recording from the ambisonic microphone array.
The footstep sounds need to track with the performer movement data.
We sync the audio position with the motion capture coordinates frame by frame.
This creates the illusion that the character is physically walking past you.
The music bed sits in the background layer at roughly thirty percent volume.
We are using a string arrangement recorded specifically for this production.
The music swells during the emotional peaks identified by the chapter detection.
I mapped the music dynamics to align with the chapter boundaries automatically.
Silence removal is crucial. There are gaps between dialogue that feel unnatural.
Our silence detection tool identified fourteen gaps longer than three seconds.
We can remove them or fill them with ambient room tone for a natural feel.
I prefer filling with room tone because hard cuts sound jarring in VR.
The final mix needs to pass loudness standards for streaming platforms.
We target negative fourteen LUFS for integrated loudness across the full program.
The limiter catches any transient peaks above negative one decibel true peak.
Audio export complete. The mix is ready for the video assembly stage.
Total processing time was under four minutes on the local GPU.
Next step is to combine this audio with the color graded video in Resolve.
The AI pipeline handles the tedious parts so we can focus on creative decisions.
Ladies and gentlemen welcome to tonight's performance.
Please silence your mobile devices and enjoy the show.
The house lights dim and the stage reveals a Victorian London street.
Fog rolls across the cobblestones as the first actor takes the stage.
The opening monologue establishes the setting and introduces the narrator.
The first scene transition uses a projected backdrop change.
The audience gasps as the scenery transforms from the street to the office.
Practical lighting effects simulate candle flame on the performers faces.
Act one ends with a dramatic reveal of the ghostly figure above the stage.
The rigging system lowers the performer on invisible wires.
The VR cameras capture the descent from multiple angles simultaneously.
Intermission. The house lights come up and the audience stretches.
Behind the curtain the stage crew is resetting for act two.
The costume change takes approximately three minutes per performer.
Act two opens with the Ghost of Christmas Present filling the stage with light.
The LED panels create a warm golden wash that contrasts with act one.
The performer improvises some of the dialogue based on audience reactions.
The emotional climax of the show brings several audience members to tears.
The lead performer delivers the redemption speech with genuine conviction.
This moment consistently receives the strongest audience response.
The final scene features the full cast on stage for the celebration.
Confetti cannons fire and the music reaches its triumphant conclusion.
The audience rises for a standing ovation that lasts nearly two minutes.
Curtain call. Each performer takes their bow individually.
The director joins the cast on stage for the final acknowledgment.
Post-show. The audience files out and the crew begins the strike.
Equipment is carefully packed and inventoried for the next venue.
The recording equipment captured six hours of raw footage tonight.
Our AI pipeline will process this into a structured library by morning.
Chapters will be detected automatically from the scene boundaries.
Final notes. The production ran twelve minutes longer than rehearsal.
The improvised dialogue sections added authenticity to the performance.
Tomorrow we review the footage and begin the post-production process.
The editing team will use the NLP command console to build the rough cut.
This has been the live performance recording for our documentation archive.
End of recording.
Exterior shot of the theater building at sunset. Golden hour light on the facade.
The marquee displays tonight's performance title in illuminated letters.
Interior lobby. Audience members arrive and collect their programs.
The art deco interior features ornate ceiling details and period lighting.
Close-up of the production program showing the cast and crew credits.
A display case shows costumes and props from previous productions.
The backstage area is buzzing with last-minute preparations.
Stage hands check the rigging while the lighting operator runs a final test.
The performers do vocal warmups in the green room before curtain.
Wide shot of the empty auditorium. The seats will be filled in twenty minutes.
Let's review the rough cut before sending it to the director for feedback.
I have assembled twenty-three clips from the three camera angles.
The AI chapter detection found eight natural scene boundaries.
I used the NLP command to add markers at each chapter boundary.
The timeline shows color-coded clips. Blue for wide shot, green for medium.
Red clips are the close-up camera and yellow clips are the interview inserts.
The color coding makes it easy to see the shot pattern at a glance.
There is a continuity issue at timecode twelve minutes thirty seconds.
The performer exits frame left on camera A but enters frame right on camera B.
We need to add a cutaway shot here to cover the transition.
The B-roll footage from the establishing shots would work well here.
Audio levels are mostly consistent. One section needs adjustment.
The audience reaction at twenty-two minutes is peaking into distortion.
I will pull the level down by three decibels and add a soft compressor.
Export settings. The final delivery is four K ProRes for archive.
We also generate an H264 proxy at 1080p for the online review platform.
Chapter markers are embedded in the file metadata for easy navigation.
Review complete. I am sending the director a link to the online preview.
She can leave timestamped comments that we import back into the timeline.
The feedback loop between director and editor is now fully automated.
Next steps are to incorporate her notes and prepare the final master.
Time to assemble the promotional trailer from our best moments.
I asked the NLP search tool to find the most dramatic segments across all clips.
The search returned twenty-four candidate segments ranked by emotional intensity.
I am selecting the top eight for the ninety-second trailer cut.
The opening shot is the exterior at golden hour. Three seconds, slow zoom.
Then we cut to the ghost reveal which tested highest with preview audiences.
The music build matches the shot transitions almost perfectly.
I am using the AI subtitle generator to add captions for social media.
The trailer needs to work in three aspect ratios for different platforms.
Sixteen by nine for YouTube. Nine by sixteen for Shorts and TikTok.
One by one for Instagram feed. The portrait crop tool handles this automatically.
Person tracking keeps the subject centered in the vertical crop.
Final trailer rendered in all three formats. Total processing time was eight minutes.
The YouTube version includes embedded chapter markers for easy preview.
I will schedule the upload for next Tuesday morning for maximum reach.
Trailer assembly is one of the most satisfying parts of the pipeline.
The AI does the heavy lifting and we get to focus on the creative choices.
Setting up for today's recording session. Let me walk you through the equipment.
We have three main camera positions plus two roaming operators.
All cameras are synced via timecode generators running at twenty-four frames per second.
The timecode sync is critical for the multi-camera editing workflow.
The audio setup uses a Dante network for digital audio distribution.
We have sixteen input channels routed to a dedicated recording interface.
The monitoring system lets us hear any channel in isolation during the show.
The motion capture volume uses twelve infrared cameras mounted on truss.
Calibration takes about twenty minutes and needs to be done before each session.
The capture resolution is sub-millimeter which gives us clean tracking data.
The tracking suits have forty-two reflective markers on each performer.
The networking rack handles all the data routing between capture systems.
We run ten gigabit ethernet to handle the bandwidth from all cameras.
The storage server has twenty terabytes of fast NVMe for live recording.
Power distribution is managed through a UPS system for uninterrupted recording.
We lost a recording once due to a power fluctuation. Never again.
The UPS provides thirty minutes of backup which covers our longest scenes.
Setup is complete. All systems are green and recording is ready to begin.
Total setup time today was one hour and forty-five minutes.
With practice the team has gotten this down from three hours last year.
Great work tonight everyone. Let us do a quick debrief while it is fresh.
Camera team, how did the new steadicam rig perform during the performance?
It was much smoother. The gimbal stabilization handled the stairs perfectly.
Good. The close-up shots from the stairs were some of the best angles we got.
Audio team. Any issues with the wireless lavaliers during the show?
Minor dropout on channel four during the scene change. We covered it with the boom.
The backup audio tracks saved us. Good call on running redundant recording.
Lighting. The color temperature shift between acts was seamless tonight.
We pre-programmed the transitions based on the rehearsal timings.
The AI chapter detection gave us accurate cue points for each transition.
Motion capture. The tracking was clean except for one brief occlusion.
When two performers crossed paths the system lost marker visibility for half a second.
The interpolation algorithm filled the gap and the audience did not notice.
Overall this was our cleanest capture session so far.
The AI pipeline will have the footage catalogued and searchable by morning.
Get some rest everyone. Editing review starts at ten tomorrow morning.
